scenes.subtitle: Vagabond Intro
scenes.text:
The road was supposed to be simple.
One town to the next. A roof, maybe a fire, then gone again before morning. That was the deal you made with yourself when you left the last place behind.
The storm came faster than expected.
Rain lashes sideways, soaking through your clothes until every step feels heavier than the last. The road ahead dissolves into mud and broken stone, the path barely visible through sheets of water and wind.
Then the lightning hits.
For a split second, the tower reveals itself—vast, looming, impossible to miss once seen. Its doors hang shattered, blasted outward as if something inside fled in desperation.
You slow your pace.
Shelter is shelter.
But you’ve learned the hard way that the places that promise safety often charge more than they give.
The wind screams louder. The cold bites deeper.
Staying out here is no longer an option.

scenes.subtitle: Lawbringer Intro
scenes.text:
The report was thin.
A disappearance. No witnesses. No body. Just a name and a location scratched into a ledger already heavy with unfinished business.
You didn’t want this assignment.
The rain hammers against your armor as you stand before the tower, its silhouette cutting through the storm like a wound in the world. The doors are destroyed—iron twisted, stone fractured outward. Not forced entry.
Something left.
You scan the ground despite the rain, eyes trained to pick out patterns in chaos. Tracks, half-erased. Signs of struggle. Or flight.
Every instinct tells you this place is wrong.
But duty doesn’t care about instinct.
Someone came here and didn’t return.
That makes it your problem.

choices.text: Arm yourself and enter the tower
Call out and look for clues

scenes.subtitle: Lightbringer Intro
scenes.text:
You felt it long before the tower came into view.
A pressure behind the eyes. A tightening in the chest. The unmistakable sensation of something unclean being allowed to persist.
The storm does nothing to drown it out.
The tower rises ahead, ancient and scarred, its doors shattered outward in violent defiance. Whatever darkness once dwelled within did not seal itself away—it tried to escape.
That alone is enough.
If corruption festers here, it does so because no one has challenged it.
You could turn away. Convince yourself that another will answer the call.
But you know better.
Evil thrives in hesitation as much as malice.

choices.text: Say a prayer and enter the tower

scenes.subtitle: Thief Intro
scenes.text:
People talk.
In taverns. In alleyways. In the quiet moments when they think no one important is listening.
Old wizard. Forbidden work. A tower left standing after everything else fell apart.
Most hear that and think curse.
You think profit.
The storm isn’t ideal, but it does one thing well—it keeps others away. Lightning flashes, revealing the tower’s broken doors, iron peeled back like they were torn open from the inside.
That’s the obvious way in.
Obvious ways are usually trapped.
Your eyes drift upward, tracing the tower’s face. Cracks. Ledges. Old stonework that wasn’t meant to be climbed—but could be.
A familiar unease settles in your gut.
You’ve ignored worse.

scenes.subtitle: Arcane Scholar Intro
scenes.text:
The damage is wrong.

That’s the first thing you notice.

The tower’s doors were not breached from the outside. The stone bears stress fractures that radiate outward, not in. Something escaped. Or attempted to.

Rain streaks over etched symbols along the threshold — not decorative, but functional. Residue lingers in the air, the faint hum of magic held in suspension.

The storm feels… reactive.

As though the world itself is pushing you forward.

You should walk away.

But knowledge like this does not present itself twice.

choices.text: Cast a protective ward and enter

scenes.subtitle: Attempt to Leave
scenes.text:
You turn away from the tower.

The rain greets you like a wall.

Wind howls across the road, louder than before, bending the world sideways. Water surges down the path you arrived on, swallowing the ruts and stones beneath it. Each step back feels heavier, slower—like the ground itself is resisting you.

You make it only a short distance before the road gives way.

Mud collapses underfoot. The path you followed here is gone, torn open by the storm and dragged downhill into the dark. What remains is impassable—a slick, churning slope that leads nowhere.

You look back.

The tower stands unchanged.

Its doors hang open, blasted outward, as if something inside once fled in desperation. Light flickers faintly within—not inviting, not welcoming—but present.

The storm presses closer behind you.

Whatever choice brought you here, the world has decided something else.

There is only one way forward now.

scenes.subtitle: Take the Main Entrance
scenes.text:
You cross the threshold.
The change is immediate.
The storm does not fade—it cuts off. Rain still lashes the shattered doors behind you, but the sound arrives late and distant, muffled by layers of stone that should not exist.
The tower does not welcome you.
It accepts you.
Inside, the air is dry and stale, carrying the faint scent of dust and old ash. Pale seams of light glow between the stones beneath your feet, dim but deliberate, like embers buried under the floor.
The doors behind you hang twisted and broken, blasted outward with violent force. Whatever came through them did not hesitate.
Ahead, the interior opens into a vast chamber. Stairways spiral upward along the walls, vanishing into shadow. Corridors slope downward into darker depths. Side halls branch away, their purposes unclear.
This place is old.
Not abandoned.
Waiting.
For a brief moment, you have the distinct impression that something is aware of you.
Watching.
Measuring.
The feeling slips away before it can take shape.
The storm surges once more against the doors—then falls silent again.
Whatever happens next will not happen on the road.
It will happen here.

scenes.subtitle: Find Another Entrance
scenes.text:
You stay in the rain longer than you should.
Circling the tower’s base, you search for anything that might pass for a safer way inside. The stone walls are slick and uneven, the mortar crumbling beneath years of neglect. Water runs in thin streams down the surface, blurring old carvings and half-erased symbols.
You look up.
The second story is too high. The windows are narrow, their edges fractured and unstable. No ledges you’d trust. No clear handholds. Whatever force broke the doors below did not bother with subtlety above.
The wind cuts harder now, driving the rain into your face. Cold settles into your bones.
There’s no way in except the obvious one.

choices.text: Give up and return to the front entrance

scenes.subtitle: Call Out and Look for Clues
scenes.text:
You raise your voice, calling out over the storm.
No answer comes back—only thunder and the hiss of rain against stone. Still, you press on, lowering yourself near the entrance despite the weather, scanning the ground for signs the storm hasn’t erased.
Footprints are scarce. Whatever happened here didn’t linger.
Closer to the doorway, you find gouges carved deep into the stone. Long, uneven scratches that tear outward from the entrance. Iron hinges are twisted in the same direction, bent as though wrenched free by brute force.
Not an intrusion.
An escape.
You straighten slowly, unease settling in your chest. Whoever disappeared here wasn’t the first thing through these doors.

scenes.subtitle: Sense the Dangers Within
scenes.text:
You draw in a steady breath and focus.
Light gathers around you, pushing back the storm’s chill as you reach outward with your senses. You search for corruption, for the familiar stain of wickedness that demands cleansing.
Something answers.
Not violently. Not eagerly.
Aware.
A presence brushes against your thoughts, immense and distant, like standing too close to a vast structure and realizing it is listening. A voice forms at the edge of perception—uncertain, incomplete.
You do not belong here.
The sensation vanishes. The light fades. The rain crashes back in full force.
Your heart pounds harder than before.
Whatever waits inside the tower is not what you expected.

choices.text: Enter the tower and confront the source

scenes.subtitle: Say a Prayer and Enter
scenes.text:
You bow your head as the storm rages around you.

Rain soaks into your cloak, cold and heavy, but you steady yourself and speak the words you were taught long ago. Not loudly. Not defiantly. A prayer meant for resolve, not protection.

For a moment, nothing happens.

Then the air shifts.

The pressure behind your eyes returns, sharper now, as if something has leaned closer to listen. The rain seems to hesitate, droplets hanging just a fraction longer before striking stone.

You feel warmth—faint, restrained—gathering in your chest.

And beneath it, something else.

A presence.

Not holy. Not unholy.

Aware.

A whisper brushes against your thoughts, too distant to understand, but unmistakably real. You cannot tell whether it comes from above, below, or all around you.

The sensation fades as quickly as it came.

The storm resumes its fury. The cold returns.

You lift your head, unsettled but resolute.

Whatever waits inside the tower heard you.

choices.text: Step through the shattered doors with renewed resolve

scenes.subtitle: Find an Alternate Way In
scenes.text:
You move around the back of the tower, keeping low and quiet.
Here, the stone shows its age—cracks in the masonry, repairs long abandoned, edges softened by time and weather. Your eyes trace a narrow route upward toward a first-story window, half-shattered and dark beyond.
You start climbing.
Rain slicks the stone beneath your fingers, but the footholds hold—until they don’t. With a sharp crack, part of the window frame crumbles away. You lunge forward, barely catching yourself as debris falls into the darkness below.
You’re stuck.
The ground is too far down to drop safely. The way back is gone. Above you, the tower rises higher, unforgiving and wet.

choices.text: Drop down and limp to the main entrance

scenes.subtitle: Climb Higher
scenes.text:
You look up.
The tower stretches above you, its stone slick with rain and age. The window you aimed for is gone now, crumbled away into darkness below. Your arms tremble as you cling to what remains, fingers numb, muscles burning.
Going down isn’t an option anymore.
You shift your weight carefully, testing the stone above you. Some holds feel solid. Others flake away at the slightest pressure. Water runs down the wall, blurring edges and making every movement uncertain.
For a moment, doubt creeps in.
Then you push it aside.
You’ve climbed worse. Broken into tighter places. Bet your life on thinner margins.
You pull yourself upward.
The stone gives way without warning.
Your grip slips. Your feet lose purchase. The world lurches violently as gravity takes hold.
You fall.

choices.text: Try to catch yourself before falling
Brace for impact and take the fall

scenes.subtitle: Catch the Fall
scenes.text:
Your hands react before your mind does.
As the stone gives way, you twist instinctively, slamming your forearm against the wall and hooking your fingers into a narrow crack you barely noticed before. Pain shoots up your arm as skin tears and muscles strain, but the momentum breaks.
You slam hard against the tower’s face, chest heaving, breath ragged.
For a moment, you hang there—soaked, shaking, alive.
Rain stings your eyes as you look around, searching for your next move. Above you, the wall offers one last narrow ledge near a darkened opening. Below you, the drop yawns wide and unforgiving.
You’ve bought yourself a chance.
But only one.

choices.text: Pull yourself up to the higher opening
Give up and drop down toward the main entrance

scenes.subtitle: Fall Hard
scenes.text:
You don’t catch yourself in time.
Your grip slips completely, and the tower vanishes from reach as gravity takes hold. The fall is short—but violent. You hit the ground hard, breath exploding from your lungs as pain rips through your side and leg.
Rain pounds down on you as you lie there, stunned and gasping.
Nothing feels broken.
But nothing feels right either.
Every movement sends sharp pain through your body, and when you try to stand, your leg buckles beneath you. You manage to stagger upright, leaning heavily on the wall for support.
Climbing again is impossible.
Whatever you hoped to gain by avoiding the main entrance, it isn’t worth this.
You limp toward the shattered doors, each step slower than the last.

choices.text: Rest briefly before forcing yourself onward

scenes.subtitle: Levitate to a Higher Entrance
scenes.text:
You steady your breathing and shape the spell in your mind.
The magic answers reluctantly. Gravity loosens its grip as you rise, rain sliding past you while the tower’s stone face draws closer. The effort is immense—far more draining than it should be—as though the tower itself resists your ascent.
You reach the second-story opening and pull yourself inside just as the spell collapses.
The world snaps back into place.
Your knees buckle. Your chest burns. The magic is gone—utterly spent—leaving a hollow ache behind your eyes.
You made it inside.
But the cost was greater than expected.

choices.text: Press on into the tower, exhausted
